captions.text: "Oh, another VR game, Yahtz? Surprised you can  even fit the headset on over your golden crown
and large, sneering, rich person moustache.  Where's the Pathologic 3 review, bitch?" Look,
I'm still playing catchup to inch my way through  January, the month equivalent of the publisher
information at the start of a not particularly  interesting book. And I present this week's review
as a direct follow-up to last week's. With Thief  VR, we discovered what happens when an IP wants
to have a VR instalment but can't be bothered to  put the proper work in. Deadpool VR, in contrast,
represents an IP wanting to have a VR instalment  and, if anything, being a little bit too bothered,
like it's the result of entire Eastern  European sweat shops of developers being
propped upright with amphetamines and stacks  of Disney money. Not Ryan Reynolds money;
it's still only the video games division; they  had to make do with Neil Patrick Harris doing
his best Ryan Reynolds impression. But look at the  rest of the voice talent they got. Jeffrey Combs,
John Leguizamo, Dolph Lundgren—it's like a party  for everyone who's just famous enough to get nerds
excited but not so famous there's an inconvenient  chance they might show up in the Epstein Files.
Anyway, regenerating, self-aware, facetious comic  book mercenary Deadpool having now graduated from
the Harley Quinn school of comic book heroism,  which is to say the unbeatable superpower of being
the most popular character, now finds himself  single-handedly manning that one arm of mainstream
superhero movies trying to keep the whole rest of  the trend afloat through the desperate assumption
that smug comedic self-effacement will somehow  come across as authentic. So he sets off on a
generic mission to fight some costumed terrorists  with an explosive playable opening sequence
featuring a car chase to the tune of Kickstart  My Heart. Now, I have only myself to blame for
this. Way back when I reviewed Guardians of the  Galaxy, I apparently let slip to Marvel's video
game division that setting combat to Kickstart My  Heart is the cheat code for immediately winning me
over. I wonder if they're still listening. Boy,  you know my favorite thing about Marvel video
games? It's when they send big bags of money to  my house. Yep, that always fast tracks a thumbs-up
for the Tomatometer. Fortunately, Deadpool VR does  manage to keep the energy level somewhat high.
The combat is all bouncing around the arena  switching between guns, melee, and grappling
dudes off of ledges to the end of appeasing a  Bulletstorm-esque stylishness scoring system and
takes another leaf from Guardians of the Galaxy  with the same "cooldown super beast mode fueled
by popular licensed music" mechanic. But the  occasions when you are fighting enough dudes to
make it feel really cool are unfortunately rare;  mostly, you activate it, kill, like, two guys, and
then the music abruptly stops like a power outage  at the roller disco. Shooting your twin handguns
works fine; damage is a bit chippy; using swords  and throwing them is fine as well, but getting
your grapple gun out requires reaching behind  your back, and that had a very poor first-time
success rate. My hands only have business behind  my back when I'm at the chiropractor or when my
bum is itching. Fortunately, there's an option to  switch that out for clicking in the thumbstick,
but that had its own problems. My large,  masculine thumbs kept clicking it by accident,
and things get very awkward when you accidentally  grapple someone you're trying to shoot. Sorry,
I didn't intend to give off mixed signals.  So that's the core combat running through
proceedings, and while I enjoyed its knockabout  fun factor, it's not particularly challenging.
Deadpool's main superpower being regeneration,  lest we forget, although how quickly and
efficiently he can do it seems to hinge on a  lot of X factors—most prominently, comic timing.
Returning to the plot, after the introductory  mission, Deadpool is kidnapped by Mojo,
an obscure Marvel character who's like  an alien intergalactic TV producer,
and incidentally, "obscure Marvel character"  is going to be the theme of the evening;
the mouse upstairs wasn't gonna let any  big names off the leash for this puerile
twaddle. I think the most well-known character  besides Deadpool who shows up is Ghost Rider,
by the basic metric of "has had their own film,"  and even then, I use the word "film" advisedly.
Deadpool is forced to work for Mojo on two fronts:  one, fight to become champion of the arena; two,
forcibly enlist a number of powerful supervillains  to also fight in the arena, which sets up what
someone with less arrested development might  call a "Twelve Labours of Hercules" framework,
but which I persist in thinking of as a "beat up  my seven evil ex-boyfriends" plot. So we have four
or five plot chapters in which Deadpool tracks  down a Marvel character who hasn't been selling
many books lately and ultimately fights them as  well as seemingly limitless quantities of minions,
and in between these, we are obliged to go to  the arena and essentially fight bot deathmatches,
which never fails to come across like  the game trying to pad its runtime out.
Yes, they try to mix up the rules each  time, but none of these missions stray
far from the formula of "kill all the dudes"  or "bring a thing to another thing and kill
all the dudes who raise an objection." I  swiftly learned to dread these interludes,
for history has shown us a comedy game lives  or dies on its ability to continually stream
new gags and funny set pieces; the moment  it starts falling back on repeatable combat
encounters with quips playing over them is when  the turd officially breaches containment and
starts pressing up against undergarment fabric.  And on that note, I appreciate that this remark
is going to highlight my lack of connection to  comic book culture, but I really wish the Merc
with a Mouth would shut the fuck up. Boy, I love  when Deadpool overshares at length while talking
facetiously to a serious character who responds  with weary frustration and eventually violence;
I only wish it had happened on more than 7,000  occasions. It seems to happen a lot in VR that
I'm frustrated by the game obviously needing me to  grab something or pull a lever but my hand keeps
phasing mysteriously through it because someone  hasn't finished talking yet. And in this game,
no one's ever fucking finished talking yet.  Not until Deadpool has figured out how to tie
in at least one pop culture reference and  then, in turn, tie that back to poo poos.
I'm not above admitting that I enjoyed  the game enough to want to finish it,
but the humor only worked for me when it  relied more on visual gags, slapstick,
and transgressive violence with maybe a bit of  dialogue to give context and emphasis like the
sprinkling of salt on caramel. At other times, the  game feels more like a single Werther's Original
in the middle of an entire jar of marmite. So in  brief, resoundingly hit and miss. Some fun ideas;
some bad parts; mostly okay combat. At the end of  the day, it was the game I chose to stick with and
chose to write this review about, whereas while I  did play Pathologic 3, I had to stop after about
an hour because I felt like I'd wandered into a  Shakespeare play mistranslated by a mad Russian
that had already started and was being repeatedly  interrupted by potentially lethal gas leaks. Just
couldn't get my head around it. Perhaps that makes  me shallow. Perhaps my attention span has been
ruined by years of the more traditional video game  dopamine reward system. Perhaps down in the gutter
with Deadpool is where I belong, but at least  it's a gutter with some decent fucking music.
